How Much Can RAG Help the Reasoning of LLM?

JingyuÂ Liu1,JiaenÂ Lin3,YongÂ Liu1,2
1Gaoling School of Artificial Intelligence, Renmin University of China, Beijing, China
2Beijing Key Laboratory of Big Data Management and Analysis Methods, Beijing, China
3School of Software Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
liuyonggsai@ruc.edu.cn
Corresponding Author.
Abstract

Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) has gained significant popularity in modern Large Language Models (LLMs) due to its effectiveness in introducing new knowledge and reducing hallucinations. However, the deep understanding of RAG remains limited, how does RAG help the reasoning process and can RAG help improve the reasoning capability remains question. While external documents are typically considered as a method to incorporate domain-specific information, they also contain intermediate reasoning results related to the query, this suggests that documents could enhance the reasoning capability of LLMs, which has not been previously explored. In this paper, we investigate this issue in depth and find that while RAG can assist with reasoning, the help is limited. If we conceptualize the reasoning process as a tree with fixed depth, then RAG struggles to assist LLMs in performing deeper reasoning. Additionally, the information in the documents requires preprocessing to filter out noise. We demonstrate that this preprocessing is difficult to achieve simply fine-tuning of the LLM, it often necessitates numerous additional transformer layers to solve the problem. To simplify the problem, we propose DPrompt tuning, which effectively resolves the issue within just limited transformer layers, leading to improved performance.

1 Introduction

Large Language Models (LLMs) (Brown, 2020) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities across a variety of tasks, including text generation and question answering (Ouyang etÂ al., 2022; Wei etÂ al., 2022), code generation (Gu, 2023), and information retrieval (Dai etÂ al., 2024). However, current LLMs often suffer from serious hallucinations (Huang etÂ al., 2023) due to a lack of factual information. Moreover, the knowledge embedded within LLMs is encoded in their parameters (Yang etÂ al., 2024), meaning that incorporating new knowledge requires further fine-tuning, which is both time-consuming and resource-intensive. Consequently, augmenting LLMs with external retrievers has led to significant performance improvements (Lewis etÂ al., 2020; Zhao etÂ al., 2024; Izacard etÂ al., 2023).

Despite the widespread adoption of RAG in modern LLMs, a comprehensive understanding of how RAG aids inference remains an open question. Most researchers currently view RAG primarily as a method to provide domain-specific knowledge (Zhang etÂ al., 2024), often seeking to adapt LLMs to particular domains through RAG (Soudani etÂ al., 2024). However, the impact of RAG on enhancing reasoning capacity has yet to be thoroughly investigated.

First, we aim to understand how RAG operates and whether it can improve the reasoning capabilities of LLMs. We can consider the LLM as computing pâ¢(y|q)ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘p(y|q)italic_p ( italic_y | italic_q ), where qğ‘qitalic_q represents the query and yğ‘¦yitalic_y is the corresponding answer. In this context, retrieval-augmented generation can be expressed as pâ¢(y|q,d1,d2,â€¦,dk)ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘subscriptğ‘‘1subscriptğ‘‘2â€¦subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘˜p(y|q,d_{1},d_{2},\ldots,d_{k})italic_p ( italic_y | italic_q , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where disubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–d_{i}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the iâ¢-thğ‘–-thi\text{-th}italic_i -th document retrieved based on the query qğ‘qitalic_q. Additionally, the well-known prompting technique, Chain of Thought (CoT) (Wei etÂ al., 2022), which significantly enhances the reasoning ability of LLMs, can be represented as pâ¢(y|q,x1,x2,â€¦,xk)ğ‘conditionalğ‘¦ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¥2â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜p(y|q,x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{k})italic_p ( italic_y | italic_q , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the step-by-step reasoning results. Both CoT and RAG aim to incorporate additional information into the input to achieve better performance. It has been theoretically demonstrated and experimentally verified that CoT effectively improves the reasoning ability of LLMs (Feng etÂ al., 2024; Wei etÂ al., 2022; Chu etÂ al., 2023). Thus, the question arises: Can RAG also enhance the reasoning capabilities of LLMs?

Fixed-depth transformer models with log precision can be simulated by constant-depth circuits (Merrill & Sabharwal, 2023), indicating that LLMs are limited to fixed-depth reasoning. When conceptualizing the reasoning path as a tree, the maximum depth remains constant (Merrill & Sabharwal, 2023). Chain of Thought (CoT) generates step-by-step reasoning or explanations rather than providing direct answers, formalized as x1=fâ¢(x),x2=fâ¢(x,x1),â€¦,y=fâ¢(x,x1,â€¦,xk)formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘“ğ‘¥formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘¥2ğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{1}=f(x),\ x_{2}=f(x,x_{1}),\ldots,y=f(x,x_{1},\ldots,x_{k})italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , italic_y = italic_f ( italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). This process allows CoT to effectively expand reasoning depth by execute fğ‘“fitalic_f multiple times, potentially reaching infinite depth with sufficient CoT steps (Feng etÂ al., 2024; Li etÂ al., 2024). In contrast, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) does not facilitate multiple inferences; instead, it retrieves existing relevant information to generate answers (Shi etÂ al., 2023b). While RAG cannot stack LLM layers to enhance reasoning capability, the retrieved documents may include intermediate reasoning results, thereby reducing the number of layers needed for inference and enabling the LLM to tackle more complex problems, thus aiding its reasoning ability.

In this paper, we first demonstrate that RAG can enhance the reasoning ability of LLMs, enabling them to tackle more complex problems. If the model can initially solve problems with a reasoning depth of lğ‘™litalic_l, then with the addition of relevant document information, it could address problems with a reasoning depth of l+cğ‘™ğ‘l+citalic_l + italic_c, where cğ‘citalic_c is a constant determined by the quality of the retrieved information. This shows that RAG can help to improve the reasoning capability of LLM.

However, in real-world RAG scenarios, the information retrieved from documents is not always directly usable and often requires further processing because documents may contain noise information (Jiang etÂ al., 2023b; a), and some documents may even be completely distracting, containing incorrect answers (Shi etÂ al., 2023a; Wu etÂ al., 2024). Such noise and distracting documents can negatively impact performance. While some works attempt to fine-tune the model to filter out noise (Xu etÂ al., 2024) and distracting documents (Yan etÂ al., 2024), these filtering processes may require additional reasoning depth and could ultimately harm overall performance. Also some works train another filter model (Yan etÂ al., 2024; Asai etÂ al., 2023), but this approach results in additional reasoning cost and makes it difficult to eliminate the inherent noise in the documents.

Therefore, a critical question arises: How difficult is the filtering problem, and can we effectively solve it within a limited number of layers? If the efforts to filter out noise is even more than the help RAG brings, RAG fail to improve the reasoning capability. First, we show that fine-tuning methods like LoRA also struggle to filter out noise without compromising reasoning capability, since filtering irrelevant tokens while maintaining the original attention patterns for relevant tokens proves challenging. This indicates that the filtering process cannot be effectively incorporated into the original reasoning steps of LLMs, necessitating additional reasoning depth for filtering, which can ultimately degrade the reasoning capability of the model.

Then we show that judging the relevance of a token can hardly be implemented by limited number of transformer layers. Considering the query â€˜Alice is exhausted but Bob is still excited; how does Bob feel?â€™ Here, â€˜exhaustedâ€™ is noise and should be excluded from the inference. However, assessing relevance necessitates considering the token â€˜Bobâ€™ in the query alongside â€˜Aliceâ€™ the subject of â€˜exhaustedâ€™. Thus, evaluating relevance requires the information from three or more tokens. Yet, the attention mechanism typically computes only pair-wise relationships, making it challenging to resolve this issue within a limited number of transformer layers (Sanford etÂ al., 2024). With the number of transformer layers required for preprocessing increases, utilizing the document information for inference would help less, and even hurt the reasoning capability. To address this, we propose DPrompt tuning which transforms the triple-wise problem into a pair-wise one, and the pair-wise problem can be effectively tackled by limited layer of transformers, ultimately enhancing the reasoning ability of Retrieval-Augmented Language Models (RALM).

The main contributions of this paper are: (1) We demonstrate that RAG can enhance the reasoning ability of LLMs; however, this improvement is limited, allowing Retrieval-Augmented Language Models (RALMs) to solve problems that require slightly more reasoning depth than before; (2) We assert that fine-tuning the model to filter out noise while preserving its original functionality is challenging. This indicates that noise would lead to worse performance even after finetuning; (3) We further reveal that the inherent triple-wise nature of the filtering process may necessitate numerous transformer layers for effective document preprocessing, which could significantly degrade reasoning ability. To address this, we propose a method to transform the problem into a pair-wise format, making it easier to solve.

In Section 2, we explore the extent to which RAG can enhance the reasoning of LLMs, demonstrating that RAG has limited potential to improve reasoning capacity. In Section 3, we discuss the negative impact of noise on performance and the challenges associated with incorporating the filtering process into the reasoning process. In Section 4, we highlight the complexities involved in judging relevance, illustrating that solving this problem requires multiple layers, and we propose a method to simplify the process.

2 How Does RAG Help Reasoning

In this section, we explore the extent to which RAG can enhance the reasoning ability of LLMs, aiming to deepen our understanding of its role in reasoning. As demonstrated by Merrill & Sabharwal (2023), transformer-based models are constrained to a fixed depth of reasoning due to the limited number of layers. Chain of Thought (CoT) facilitates step-by-step reasoning, effectively stacking multiple LLMs to address a single problem. Thus, the question is: How can RAG assist during the reasoning process, and how much additional reasoning capacity can RAG provide to LLMs?

2.1 The fission of RAG

If we consider the reasoning steps of an LLM as a tree, the maximum reasoning depth is fixed at Lğ¿Litalic_L due to the constraints of the depth of the model. Additionally, the maximum width of this tree is also limited, as the number of attention heads per layer is finite. For a reasoning tree ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T with Lğ¿Litalic_L layers, let the number of nodes in layer iğ‘–iitalic_i be denoted as nisubscriptğ‘›ğ‘–n_{i}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and refer to the jâ¢-thğ‘—-thj\text{-th}italic_j -th node in the iâ¢-thğ‘–-thi\text{-th}italic_i -th layer as ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The retrieved document dğ‘‘ditalic_d contains relevant information that can be leveraged to replace certain reasoning nodes with extracted document content. For instance, consider the query Who is the actor playing Jason on General Hospital?â€™ (Yoran etÂ al., 2023). In this scenario, there may be a node ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT representing the information about What is General Hospital?â€™. If we provide a document containing detailed information about General Hospital, the computation for ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can effectively be replaced by extracting relevant information from that document.

Definition 2.1 (Reasoning Tree).

For a reasoning tree ğ’¯Lsubscriptğ’¯ğ¿{\mathcal{T}}_{L}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Lğ¿Litalic_L layers, and there are nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT nodes in each layer lğ‘™litalic_l, nLâˆ’1=1subscriptğ‘›ğ¿11n_{L-1}=1italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, all nodes in layer lğ‘™litalic_l are connected to at least to one node in layer l+1ğ‘™1l+1italic_l + 1. with probability 1âˆ’ql1subscriptğ‘ğ‘™1-q_{l}1 - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, node ul,isubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘–u_{l,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are connected to ul+1,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™1ğ‘—u_{l+1,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the isolated nodes are randomly connected to a node in case of useless nodes.

In the reasoning tree, each node represents a calculation, with the output being some intermediate reasoning results. The connection between nodes ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and uiâˆ’1,ksubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–1ğ‘˜u_{i-1,k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indicates that the calculation of ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT relies on the output of uiâˆ’1,ksubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–1ğ‘˜u_{i-1,k}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - 1 , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The parameter qlsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™q_{l}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reflects the sparsity of these connections. Consequently, for a node ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a document may contain relevant information, allowing the calculation for ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be effectively replaced by information extracted from the document.

Definition 2.2 (Retrieval).

For a reasoning tree ğ’¯Lsubscriptğ’¯ğ¿{\mathcal{T}}_{L}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with probability plsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™p_{l}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the nodes in layer lğ‘™litalic_l can be replaced by retrieved documents.

Itâ€™s important to recognize that processing documents also necessitates a certain depth of reasoning. However, extracting information from a document is fundamentally an information extraction process, whereas directly addressing a query is a purely inferential process. Therefore, we can assume that the cost of information extraction is lower than that of inference. This enables LLMs to leverage external information, thereby simplifying complex reasoning tasks.

Assumption 2.3.

If the document dğ‘‘ditalic_d contains information about node uğ‘¢uitalic_u at the lâ¢-â¢tâ¢hğ‘™-ğ‘¡â„l\text{-}thitalic_l - italic_t italic_h layer, then only Î»â‹…lâ‹…ğœ†ğ‘™\lambda\cdot litalic_Î» â‹… italic_l layers are needed to extract the information from dğ‘‘ditalic_d, Î»<1ğœ†1\lambda<1italic_Î» < 1.

This assumption suggests that while processing documents requires some reasoning depth, it is generally shallower than the inference needed for directly addressing a query. Therefore, utilizing information from documents should be a more efficient solution. In this way, RAG can eliminate certain nodes and potentially enhance the expressive power of LLMs. However, this also indicates that RAG cannot completely minimize reasoning depth, as some layers are necessary for document processing. Consequently, for a reasoning tree ğ’¯Lsubscriptğ’¯ğ¿{\mathcal{T}}_{L}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, at least Î»â‹…Lâ‹…ğœ†ğ¿\lambda\cdot Litalic_Î» â‹… italic_L layers will be required to process the documents, even if we retrieve the documents directly lead to the answer.

The document not only simplifies the calculation of ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but also eliminates all nodes that are solely connected to ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. These nodes contribute only to the reasoning of ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and since the information of ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be directly derived from the document, their reasoning is rendered unnecessary. Thus, retrieving a single document related to node ui,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘—u_{i,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can result in the reduction of multiple lower-layer nodes. This process is similar to fission reactions in nuclear weapons, where the reduction of one node triggers the reduction of many others. Consequently, if all nodes in the lâ€²superscriptğ‘™â€²l^{\prime}italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTth layer are reduced by the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) method, any layer where lâ‰¤lâ€²ğ‘™superscriptğ‘™â€²l\leq l^{\prime}italic_l â‰¤ italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can also be eliminated, effectively decreasing the overall reasoning depth.

As illustrated in Figure 1, the reasoning tree consists of 4 layers, and we have retrieved 3 documents that provide information for nodes u2,0subscriptğ‘¢20u_{2,0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, u1,1subscriptğ‘¢11u_{1,1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and u2,2subscriptğ‘¢22u_{2,2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. and with document Dâ¢1ğ·1D1italic_D 1, node u1,0subscriptğ‘¢10u_{1,0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can also be erased because it contributes only to u2,0subscriptğ‘¢20u_{2,0}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and with Dâ¢2ğ·2D2italic_D 2, u0,1subscriptğ‘¢01u_{0,1}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not also necessary, the same applies to node u1,2subscriptğ‘¢12u_{1,2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and u1,3subscriptğ‘¢13u_{1,3}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT because of Dâ¢3ğ·3D3italic_D 3. Consequently, all 4 nodes in layer 1 can be either accessed or reduced through the documents, meaning that all nodes in layer 1 and 0 are unnecessary. This results in a reasoning depth of 2 instead of 4. Thus, with relevant documents, RAG can effectively reduce the reasoning complexity of the problem, enabling the LLM to solve problems of higher complexity.

We can observe that the elimination of a single node can significantly impact numerous nodes in shallower layers, much like a fission reaction. If this fission process can expand effectively, RAG could greatly enhance the reasoning capacity of LLMs. However, if the fission reaction halts at a certain threshold, the benefits may be limited. Therefore, to assess how many layers can be reduced by RAG, it is essential to determine whether this fission-like process can terminate. Understanding this dynamic is crucial for evaluating how RAG can improve reasoning capabilities and the overall efficiency of LLMs in complex problem-solving scenarios.

Consider a reasoning tree ğ’¯Lsubscriptğ’¯ğ¿{\mathcal{T}}_{L}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let tl+1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™1t_{l+1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stands for the percentage of erased nodes in layer l+1ğ‘™1l+1italic_l + 1, then the probability of one node being erased in layer lğ‘™litalic_l is affected by tl+1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™1t_{l+1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the retrieval probability plsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™p_{l}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the sparsity of the layer qlsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™q_{l}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let tl=fâ¢(tl+1,pl,ql)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘™t_{l}=f(t_{l+1},p_{l},q_{l})italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), in the following of the paper, we will omit pl,ql,tl+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™1p_{l},q_{l},t_{l+1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, using simply tl=fâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™ğ‘“ğ‘¡t_{l}=f(t)italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_t ).

The function fâ¢(t)ğ‘“ğ‘¡f(t)italic_f ( italic_t ) is expected to be increasing with respect to tğ‘¡titalic_t, with fâ¢(0)=plğ‘“0subscriptğ‘ğ‘™f(0)=p_{l}italic_f ( 0 ) = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and fâ¢(1)=1ğ‘“11f(1)=1italic_f ( 1 ) = 1. Defining gâ¢(t)=fâ¢(t)âˆ’tğ‘”ğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘¡g(t)=f(t)-titalic_g ( italic_t ) = italic_f ( italic_t ) - italic_t, which represents growth in layer lğ‘™litalic_l, we can consider the existence of a point t^âˆˆ(0,1)^ğ‘¡01\hat{t}\in(0,1)over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) where gâ¢(t^)=0ğ‘”^ğ‘¡0g(\hat{t})=0italic_g ( over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) = 0. If for t>t^ğ‘¡^ğ‘¡t>\hat{t}italic_t > over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG, gâ¢(t)<0ğ‘”ğ‘¡0g(t)<0italic_g ( italic_t ) < 0, this indicates that the expected number of erased nodes will be smaller than in the previous layer, suggesting that the fission reaction will not propagate indefinitely but will instead reach a critical threshold. Beyond this point, the number of nodes eliminated in the subsequent layer is expected to decrease compared to the current layer, thereby limiting the expansion of the fission reaction.

Theorem 2.4 (Fission of RAG).

Let tlsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™t_{l}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the percentage of erased nodes in layer lğ‘™litalic_l, and let n=nl+1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘™1n=n_{l+1}italic_n = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then for layer lğ‘™litalic_l, if the retrival probability pl<1âˆ’1qlnâˆ’lnâ¡qlnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™11superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›p_{l}<1-\frac{1}{q_{l}^{n}-\ln q_{l}^{n}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_ln italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, then there exists t^âˆˆ(0,1)^ğ‘¡01\hat{t}\in(0,1)over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) satisfying gâ¢(t^)=0ğ‘”^ğ‘¡0g(\hat{t})=0italic_g ( over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ) = 0, and for t>t^ğ‘¡^ğ‘¡t>\hat{t}italic_t > over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG, gâ¢(t)<0ğ‘”ğ‘¡0g(t)<0italic_g ( italic_t ) < 0.

The proof is detailed in Appendix A.1. This theorem indicates that the erased nodes cannot propagate indefinitely like a fission reaction; rather, they will stop at a certain threshold. Specifically, when pl<1âˆ’1qlnâˆ’lnâ¡qlnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™11superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›p_{l}<1-\frac{1}{q_{l}^{n}-\ln q_{l}^{n}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_ln italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG and tâ‰¥t^ğ‘¡^ğ‘¡t\geq\hat{t}italic_t â‰¥ over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG, it follows that fâ¢(t)â‰¤tğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘¡f(t)\leq titalic_f ( italic_t ) â‰¤ italic_t. As illustrated in Figure 2, if xâ‰¤t^ğ‘¥^ğ‘¡x\leq\hat{t}italic_x â‰¤ over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG, the probability of erasure increases, whereas for x>t^ğ‘¥^ğ‘¡x>\hat{t}italic_x > over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG, it gradually decreases, stabilizing at t^^ğ‘¡\hat{t}over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG.

The existence of t^^ğ‘¡\hat{t}over^ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG primarily depends on plsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™p_{l}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and qlnsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›q_{l}^{n}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In a regular reasoning tree, there are fewer nodes at the top and more nodes in shallower layers, resulting in tighter connections (smaller qğ‘qitalic_q and nğ‘›nitalic_n at higher levels). Define hâ¢(q,n)=1âˆ’1qlnâˆ’lnâ¡qlnâ„ğ‘ğ‘›11superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›h(q,n)=1-\frac{1}{q_{l}^{n}-\ln q_{l}^{n}}italic_h ( italic_q , italic_n ) = 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_ln italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. Assuming qâˆˆ[0.1,0.8]ğ‘0.10.8q\in[0.1,0.8]italic_q âˆˆ [ 0.1 , 0.8 ] and nâˆˆ[2,16]ğ‘›216n\in[2,16]italic_n âˆˆ [ 2 , 16 ], with qiâˆ’qj=Î·â¢(niâˆ’nj)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğœ‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘—q_{i}-q_{j}=\eta(n_{i}-n_{j})italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î· ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we find that hâ¢(q,n)â‰¥0.7â„ğ‘ğ‘›0.7h(q,n)\geq 0.7italic_h ( italic_q , italic_n ) â‰¥ 0.7. This suggests that to sustain the fission reaction, we need to retrieve most intermediate reasoning results, which becomes challenging in higher layers, as we mainly retrieve information about basic concepts during reasoning. Consequently, this leads to the termination of the fission reaction in those upper layers. We set the maximal nğ‘›nitalic_n as 16 because Merrill & Sabharwal (2023) shows that two heads can simulate one reasoning node in the circuits, and for LLMs with 32 heads, the maximal nğ‘›nitalic_n is 16, and with larger nğ‘›nitalic_n, hâ¢(q,n)â„ğ‘ğ‘›h(q,n)italic_h ( italic_q , italic_n ) increases, making it harder for the fission reaction to continue.

Now we consider the scenario where the fission reaction converges to a certain point and calculate the probability of erasing a layer. As the probability of replacing a node approaches tl^^subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™\hat{t_{l}}over^ start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, we assume that the probability of replacing a node in layer lğ‘™litalic_l is tl^^subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™\hat{t_{l}}over^ start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, i.e., tl=tl^subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™^subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™t_{l}=\hat{t_{l}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. In Appendix A.2, we demonstrate through simulation that tlâ‰ˆtl^subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™^subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™t_{l}\approx\hat{t_{l}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ over^ start_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, which validates our assumption.

Theorem 2.5.

With pl<1âˆ’1qnâˆ’nâ¢lnâ¡qsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™11superscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘p_{l}<1-\frac{1}{q^{n}-n\ln q}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_n roman_ln italic_q end_ARG, if we want probability Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ that all nodes in layer lğ‘™litalic_l can be replaced by document information, we need plâ‰³1âˆ’Ïµ1âˆ’qÏµâ¢ngreater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘™1italic-Ïµ1superscriptğ‘italic-Ïµğ‘›p_{l}\gtrsim 1-\frac{\epsilon}{1-q^{\epsilon n}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰³ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ïµ italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, and Ïµâ‰¤1âˆ’Î´nitalic-Ïµ1ğ‘›ğ›¿\epsilon\leq 1-\sqrt[n]{\delta}italic_Ïµ â‰¤ 1 - nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG.

The proof is presented in Appendix A.2. According to the theorem, 1âˆ’Ïµ1âˆ’qÏµâ¢n1italic-Ïµ1superscriptğ‘italic-Ïµğ‘›1-\frac{\epsilon}{1-q^{\epsilon n}}1 - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ïµ italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG is decreasing with Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ, so for a feasible solution, we require a large Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ, i.e., a small Î´nğ‘›ğ›¿\sqrt[n]{\delta}nth-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG. Considering a similar scenario with qâˆˆ[0.1,0.8]ğ‘0.10.8q\in[0.1,0.8]italic_q âˆˆ [ 0.1 , 0.8 ] and nâˆˆ[2,16]ğ‘›216n\in[2,16]italic_n âˆˆ [ 2 , 16 ], where qiâˆ’qj=Î·â¢(niâˆ’nj)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğœ‚subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘—q_{i}-q_{j}=\eta(n_{i}-n_{j})italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Î· ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), as shown in Figure 3, high-probability layer erasure is primarily achievable in lower layers, as we cannot retrieve much information from higher layers. However, we also observe that with a small probability, effectively erasing higher layers is possible, indicating that RAG can significantly enhance LLM reasoning. This suggests that if we are fortunate enough to retrieve documents that directly lead to the answer, we can substantially reduce reasoning complexity. Nonetheless, in typical scenarios, the assistance is limited since most retrieved documents contain only basic information.

3 Noise in the Document

In real-world applications of RAG, Due to the limited capacity of the retriever, distractions frequently arise in the retrieved documents (Shi etÂ al., 2023a; Wu etÂ al., 2024). Moreover, even in relevant documents, the presence of noise information is common (Jiang etÂ al., 2023b; a; Xu etÂ al., 2024). So we cannot directly use the information from retrieved documents; further processing is necessary because those noise and distracting information can be mistakenly interpreted as relevant, significantly degrading the performance of RALM. In this section, we examine the extent to which distracting and noisy information impacts overall performance.

For a token ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}bold_italic_x, we assume that its embedding contains two distinct pieces of information: ğ’˜ğ’˜{\bm{w}}bold_italic_w, which acts as the regressor to determine the relevance of the document to the query, and ğ’”ğ’”{\bm{s}}bold_italic_s, representing other information useful for inference. Thus, we can express the relationship as Hâ¢(ğ’™)=Hâ¢(ğ’”,ğ’˜)ğ»ğ’™ğ»ğ’”ğ’˜H({\bm{x}})=H({\bm{s}},{\bm{w}})italic_H ( bold_italic_x ) = italic_H ( bold_italic_s , bold_italic_w ), where Hâ¢(â‹…)ğ»â‹…H(\cdot)italic_H ( â‹… ) denotes entropy. Let ğ’›ğ’›{\bm{z}}bold_italic_z be the token embedding after passing through the transformer layers, and let ğ’=[ğ’›1T,â€¦,ğ’›nT]ğ’superscriptsubscriptğ’›1ğ‘‡â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ’›ğ‘›ğ‘‡{\bm{Z}}=[{\bm{z}}_{1}^{T},\ldots,{\bm{z}}_{n}^{T}]bold_italic_Z = [ bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], where nğ‘›nitalic_n is the sequence length. We use ğ’rsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ{\bm{Z}}_{r}bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to denote the embeddings of the related tokens.

When generating new tokens, the token embedding is integrated into the inference process. Therefore, if more information about ğ’˜ğ’˜{\bm{w}}bold_italic_w is incorporated into ğ’›ğ’›{\bm{z}}bold_italic_z (resulting in a high Iâ¢(ğ’˜;ğ’›)ğ¼ğ’˜ğ’›I({\bm{w}};{\bm{z}})italic_I ( bold_italic_w ; bold_italic_z )), the model can effectively recognize irrelevant tokens when conducting inference. Conversely, if the information is limited, the model is likely to be significantly affected by noise and distracting information in the input.

Theorem 3.1 (Impact of Noise).

Given a set of input tokens, with Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ percent of related and 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ percent of distractions. If we assume documents contribute the same, and LLM conducts the filtering before inference, then

â„’â¢(Î´)âˆ’â„’â¢(1)â‰¤c1â¢((1âˆ’Î´)â¢Hâ¢(ğ’˜|ğ’›)Î´â¢(Iâ¢(ğ’˜;ğ’›)+1))â‹…Hâ¢(ğ’r)+c2,â„’ğ›¿â„’1subscriptğ‘1â‹…1ğ›¿ğ»conditionalğ’˜ğ’›ğ›¿ğ¼ğ’˜ğ’›1ğ»subscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘2\mathcal{L}(\delta)-\mathcal{L}(1)\leq c_{1}\sqrt{\left(\frac{(1-\delta)H({\bm% {w}}|{\bm{z}})}{\delta(I({\bm{w}};{\bm{z}})+1)}\right)\cdot H({\bm{Z}}_{r})}+c% _{2},caligraphic_L ( italic_Î´ ) - caligraphic_L ( 1 ) â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG ( divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î´ ) italic_H ( bold_italic_w | bold_italic_z ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ ( italic_I ( bold_italic_w ; bold_italic_z ) + 1 ) end_ARG ) â‹… italic_H ( bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (1)

where â„’â¢(Î´)â„’ğ›¿\mathcal{L}(\delta)caligraphic_L ( italic_Î´ ) stands for the loss with Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ percent of relevant documents and â„’â¢(1)â„’1\mathcal{L}(1)caligraphic_L ( 1 ) means the loss with all information related to the query, no distraction is involved. ğ³ğ³{\bm{z}}bold_italic_z is the embedding of documents, Hâ¢(â‹…)ğ»â‹…H(\cdot)italic_H ( â‹… ) and Iâ¢(â‹…;â‹…)ğ¼â‹…â‹…I(\cdot;\cdot)italic_I ( â‹… ; â‹… ) represents the entropy and mutual information. c1,c2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2c_{1},c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are constants and the value is shown in Appendix B.1.

The proof is presented in Appendix B.1. From Equation 1, we see that the generalization error decreases as Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ increases. This indicates that if not all information needed to distinguish irrelevant tokens is captured in the embedding, an increasing number of distracting documents will have negative affect on performance. The term Hâ¢(ğ’r)ğ»subscriptğ’ğ‘ŸH({\bm{Z}}_{r})italic_H ( bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) represents the amount of relevant token information utilized to infer the final result, suggesting that the greater the reliance of the LLM on documents, the more detrimental the impact of noise becomes. Furthermore, performance is primarily determined by Iâ¢(ğ’˜;ğ’›)ğ¼ğ’˜ğ’›I({\bm{w}};{\bm{z}})italic_I ( bold_italic_w ; bold_italic_z ), which quantifies the information in the embedding relevant for assessing the documentâ€™s relevance. Recent studies indicate that LLMs effectively perform information compression (DelÃ©tang etÂ al., 2023; Huang etÂ al., 2024; Yu etÂ al., 2023), retaining only the information pertinent to the downstream task while discarding extraneous noise, specifically Hâ¢(ğ’›|ğ’”)ğ»conditionalğ’›ğ’”H({\bm{z}}|{\bm{s}})italic_H ( bold_italic_z | bold_italic_s ). Consequently, only limited information about how to differentiate irrelevant documents is preserved, leading to diminished performance.

3.1 Finetuning Helps But not Perfectly

Clearly, noise in the documents negatively impacts the performance of LLMs. Some researchers focus on fine-tuning the model to better filter out irrelevant documents, thereby enhancing performance (Yoran etÂ al., 2023; Zhang etÂ al., 2024; Jiang etÂ al., 2023b). However, filtering out noise may require additional reasoning layers, which could hinder the reasoning ability of RALM. Therefore, we aim to explore whether we can incorporate the filtering process into the reasoning process, specifically addressing the question: can we filter out irrelevant information while conducting the original inference?

Let ğ’“ğ’“{\bm{r}}bold_italic_r represents the relevance of tokens, ri=0subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–0r_{i}=0italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 means that token ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a noise token, otherwise the token is relevant. Let aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢nâ¢(ğ’™i,ğ’™j)=(ğ‘¾qâ¢ğ’™i)Tâ¢ğ‘¾kâ¢ğ’™jğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘subscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘—attn({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{j})=({\bm{W}}_{q}{\bm{x}}_{i})^{T}{\bm{W}}_{k}{\bm% {x}}_{j}italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represent the original attention layer of the LLM. And we assume that the desired self-attention function is:

aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢n^â¢(ğ’™i,ğ’™j)={0Â ifÂ â¢rj=0,(ğ‘¾qâ¢ğ’™i)Tâ¢ğ‘¾kâ¢ğ’™jÂ else,Â ^ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘—cases0Â ifÂ subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘—0superscriptsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘subscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘—Â else,Â \widehat{attn}({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{j})=\begin{cases}0&\text{ if }\ r_{j}=0,% \\ ({\bm{W}}_{q}{\bm{x}}_{i})^{T}{\bm{W}}_{k}{\bm{x}}_{j}&\text{ else, }\end{cases}over^ start_ARG italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n end_ARG ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ( bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL else, end_CELL end_ROW (2)

The desired attention pattern should effectively exclude noise while preserving the original attention of relevant tokens. We assume that, in the presence of relevant tokens, the original model represents the optimal solution, as it is specifically trained to address the problem. Therefore, aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢n^^ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘›\widehat{attn}over^ start_ARG italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n end_ARG can be considered the optimal response when confronted with noise, as it effectively filters out irrelevant tokens and utilizes the relevant information in the most efficient manner.

Finetuning the model involves adjusting its parameters, which allows the finetuned model to be expressed as aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢nâ€²â¢(ğ’™i,ğ’™j)=((ğ‘¾q+Î”â¢ğ‘¾q)â¢ğ’™i)Tâ¢(ğ‘¾k+Î”â¢ğ‘¾k)â¢ğ’™j=ğ’™iTâ¢(ğ‘¾+Î”â¢ğ‘¾)â¢ğ’™jğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘Î”subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘subscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜Î”subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğ‘¾Î”ğ‘¾subscriptğ’™ğ‘—attn^{\prime}({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{j})=\left(({\bm{W}}_{q}+\Delta{\bm{W}}_{q% }){\bm{x}}_{i}\right)^{T}\left({\bm{W}}_{k}+\Delta{\bm{W}}_{k}\right){\bm{x}}_% {j}={\bm{x}}_{i}^{T}({\bm{W}}+\Delta{\bm{W}}){\bm{x}}_{j}italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( ( bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Î” bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Î” bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_W + roman_Î” bold_italic_W ) bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ğ‘¾=ğ‘¾qTâ¢ğ‘¾kğ‘¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜{\bm{W}}={\bm{W}}_{q}^{T}{\bm{W}}_{k}bold_italic_W = bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î”â¢ğ‘¾Î”ğ‘¾\Delta{\bm{W}}roman_Î” bold_italic_W represents the adjustments. The critical question arises: can we finetune the model to approximate the optimal one, i.e., is there a Î”â¢ğ‘¾Î”ğ‘¾\Delta{\bm{W}}roman_Î” bold_italic_W such that Ïƒâ¢(aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢nâ€²â¢(ğ’™i,ğ’™j))â‰ˆÏƒâ¢(aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢n^â¢(ğ’™i,ğ’™j))ğœğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘—ğœ^ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘—\sigma(attn^{\prime}({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{j}))\approx\sigma(\widehat{attn}({% \bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{j}))italic_Ïƒ ( italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) â‰ˆ italic_Ïƒ ( over^ start_ARG italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n end_ARG ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) )? Ïƒâ¢(â‹…)ğœâ‹…\sigma(\cdot)italic_Ïƒ ( â‹… ) represents the softmax.

Theorem 3.2.

if there exists aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢nâ€²â¢(ğ±i,ğ±j)=ğ±iâ¢(ğ–+Î”â¢ğ–)â¢ğ±jğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘—subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ–Î”ğ–subscriptğ±ğ‘—attn^{\prime}({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{j})={\bm{x}}_{i}({\bm{W}}+\Delta{\bm{W}})% {\bm{x}}_{j}italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_W + roman_Î” bold_italic_W ) bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ approximates aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢n^â¢(ğ±i,ğ±j)^ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘—\widehat{attn}({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{j})over^ start_ARG italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n end_ARG ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) i.e.,Â (1âˆ’Ïµ)â¢Ïƒâ¢(aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢n^â¢(xi,xj))â‰¤Ïƒâ¢(aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢nâ€²â¢(xi,xj))â‰¤(1+Ïµ)â¢Ïƒâ¢(aâ¢tâ¢tâ¢n^â¢(xi,xj))1italic-Ïµğœ^ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğœğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘›â€²subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—1italic-Ïµğœ^ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—(1-\epsilon)\sigma(\widehat{attn}(x_{i},x_{j}))\leq\sigma(attn^{\prime}(x_{i},% x_{j}))\leq(1+\epsilon)\sigma(\widehat{attn}(x_{i},x_{j}))( 1 - italic_Ïµ ) italic_Ïƒ ( over^ start_ARG italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n end_ARG ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) â‰¤ italic_Ïƒ ( italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) â‰¤ ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) italic_Ïƒ ( over^ start_ARG italic_a italic_t italic_t italic_n end_ARG ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), then we need

Î´â‰²lnâ¡11âˆ’Ïµ,less-than-or-similar-toğ›¿11italic-Ïµ\delta\lesssim\ln\frac{1}{1-\epsilon},italic_Î´ â‰² roman_ln divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Ïµ end_ARG ,

where Î´=maxâ¡(ğ±iTâ¢Î”â¢ğ–â¢ğ±j)âˆ’minâ¡(ğ±iTâ¢Î”â¢ğ–â¢ğ±j)ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘‡Î”ğ–subscriptğ±ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘‡Î”ğ–subscriptğ±ğ‘—\delta=\max({\bm{x}}_{i}^{T}\Delta{\bm{W}}{\bm{x}}_{j})-\min({\bm{x}}_{i}^{T}% \Delta{\bm{W}}{\bm{x}}_{j})italic_Î´ = roman_max ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” bold_italic_W bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_min ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” bold_italic_W bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and xjsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a relevant token.

The proof is presented in Appendix B.2. To effectively fine-tune the model for filtering out irrelevant information in the attention matrix, we need Î´â‰ˆ0ğ›¿0\delta\approx 0italic_Î´ â‰ˆ 0. This implies that for all tokens to be retained, ğ’™iTâ¢ğ‘¾â¢ğ’™jsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğ‘¾subscriptğ’™ğ‘—{\bm{x}}_{i}^{T}{\bm{W}}{\bm{x}}_{j}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must remain nearly constant. As a result, approximating the optimal solution proves to be quite challenging.

Since the self-attention layer struggles to filter out irrelevant information while maintaining optimal reasoning performance, a pertinent question arises: can the feed-forward network connected to the self-attention layer effectively filter out mistakenly incorporated information? Here, we denote the information necessary to assess the relevance of the involved tokens as ğ’˜^^ğ’˜\hat{{\bm{w}}}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG, so Hâ¢(ğ’˜^)=Hâ¢(ğ’˜iâ¢1,ğ’˜iâ¢2,â€¦)ğ»^ğ’˜ğ»subscriptğ’˜ğ‘–1subscriptğ’˜ğ‘–2â€¦H(\hat{{\bm{w}}})=H({\bm{w}}_{i1},{\bm{w}}_{i2},\ldots)italic_H ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG ) = italic_H ( bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ ), where ğ’˜iâ¢jsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘—{\bm{w}}_{ij}bold_italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the relevance information of the token aggregated by self-attention and those tokens form the input to the feed forward layer.

Theorem 3.3.

For a Feed Forward Network fğ‘“fitalic_f and the input embedding vğ‘£vitalic_v contains 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta1 - italic_Î´ percent of noise information, assume the optimal function is f^â¢(x)^ğ‘“ğ‘¥\hat{f}(x)over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) which filter out the noise and finish the inference, then

Prâ¡(â€–fâ¢(x)âˆ’f^â¢(x)â€–>tâ€²)>1Câ¢(Hâ¢(ğ’—)âˆ’Î´â¢Iâ¢(ğ’˜^;ğ’—)+1Hâ¢(ğ’˜^)â‹…Iâ¢(ğ’”;ğ’—)),Prnormğ‘“ğ‘¥^ğ‘“ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¡â€²1ğ¶ğ»ğ’—â‹…ğ›¿ğ¼^ğ’˜ğ’—1ğ»^ğ’˜ğ¼ğ’”ğ’—\begin{split}&\Pr\left(||f(x)-\hat{f}(x)||>t^{\prime}\right)>\frac{1}{C}\left(% H({\bm{v}})-\delta\frac{I(\hat{{\bm{w}}};{\bm{v}})+1}{H(\hat{{\bm{w}}})}\cdot I% ({\bm{s}};{\bm{v}})\right),\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL roman_Pr ( | | italic_f ( italic_x ) - over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_x ) | | > italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) > divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_C end_ARG ( italic_H ( bold_italic_v ) - italic_Î´ divide start_ARG italic_I ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG ; bold_italic_v ) + 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_H ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG ) end_ARG â‹… italic_I ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_v ) ) , end_CELL end_ROW (3)

where tğ‘¡titalic_t is a constant, tâ€²=t+c1â¢(1âˆ’Î´)â¢Hâ¢(ğ°^|ğ¯)âˆ’1Hâ¢(ğ°^)â‹…Iâ¢(ğ¬;ğ¯)+c2superscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘1â‹…1ğ›¿ğ»conditional^ğ°ğ¯1ğ»^ğ°ğ¼ğ¬ğ¯subscriptğ‘2t^{\prime}=t+c_{1}\sqrt{(1-\delta)\frac{H(\hat{{\bm{w}}}|{\bm{v}})-1}{H(\hat{{% \bm{w}}})}\cdot I({\bm{s}};{\bm{v}})}+c_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_t + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG ( 1 - italic_Î´ ) divide start_ARG italic_H ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG | bold_italic_v ) - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_H ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG ) end_ARG â‹… italic_I ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_v ) end_ARG + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hâ¢(ğ¯)ğ»ğ¯H({\bm{v}})italic_H ( bold_italic_v ) stands for all the information needed to conduct inference. C=logâ¡|ğ’±|Nmâ¢aâ¢xâ¢(t)ğ¶ğ’±subscriptğ‘ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¡C=\log\frac{|\mathcal{\mathcal{V}}|}{N_{max}(t)}italic_C = roman_log divide start_ARG | caligraphic_V | end_ARG start_ARG italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_a italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_ARG is a constant and we show it in the Appendix.

The proof is detailed in Appendix B.3. From the above theorem, it is evident that achieving better performance requires the input to incorporate information that effectively distinguishes irrelevant tokens (a large Iâ¢(ğ’˜^;ğ’—)ğ¼^ğ’˜ğ’—I(\hat{{\bm{w}}};{\bm{v}})italic_I ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG ; bold_italic_v )) and the necessary information for inference (a large Iâ¢(ğ’”;ğ’—)ğ¼ğ’”ğ’—I({\bm{s}};{\bm{v}})italic_I ( bold_italic_s ; bold_italic_v )). Additionally, there should be minimal noise incorporated into the input (a large Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´). As previously noted, the self-attention module struggles to filter out irrelevant information while retaining relevant tokens, which makes it difficult to increase Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´. Furthermore, it is difficult to integrate additional information about ğ’˜^^ğ’˜\hat{{\bm{w}}}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG (i.e., to increase Iâ¢(ğ’˜^;ğ’—)ğ¼^ğ’˜ğ’—I(\hat{{\bm{w}}};{\bm{v}})italic_I ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_w end_ARG ; bold_italic_v )) because the input to the MLP layer is given by ğ’—=âˆ‘jai,jâ¢ğ’™jâ¢ğ‘¾vğ’—subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ’™ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘£{\bm{v}}=\sum_{j}a_{i,j}{\bm{x}}_{j}{\bm{W}}_{v}bold_italic_v = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, resulting in ğ’—ğ’—{\bm{v}}bold_italic_v being an embedding of dimension mğ‘šmitalic_m and precision pğ‘pitalic_p. This limited dimensionality makes it challenging to encapsulate all the necessary information for filtering out irrelevant documents for all involved tokens. Consequently, the Feed Forward Layer is unlikely to achieve optimal performance when dealing with noisy input.

4 Extra Lyaers for Filtering

Clearly, noise in the documents adversely affects the performance of large language models (LLMs), and filtering out this information without compromising the performance ability of the retrieval-augmented language model (RALM) is challenging. Additional layers are necessary for effectively filtering out irrelevant information. If we cannot resolve the filtering issue within a limited number of layers, the overall reasoning capability of the RALM may fall below that of standard reasoning models, resulting in retrieved documents failing to enhance the reasoning abilities of the LLM. Therefore, the crucial question is: how many layers are required to effectively address the filtering problem?

4.1 The Triple-Wise Problem

For an input sequence ğ‘¿=[ğ’™0T,ğ’™1T,â€¦,ğ’™nâˆ’1T]ğ‘¿superscriptsubscriptğ’™0ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ’™1ğ‘‡â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘›1ğ‘‡{\bm{X}}=[{\bm{x}}_{0}^{T},{\bm{x}}_{1}^{T},\ldots,{\bm{x}}_{n-1}^{T}]bold_italic_X = [ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], the vector ğ’“ğ’“{\bm{r}}bold_italic_r indicates the relevance of each token. Specifically, for each token ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, a relevance score of ri=0subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–0r_{i}=0italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 signifies that the token is irrelevant to the query. Itâ€™s crucial to note that calculating risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not solely depend on the token embedding ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the query; rather, it may require the involvement of three or more tokens. For instance, in the query â€œAlice is exhausted, but Bob is still very excited, showing no signs of fatigue. How does Bob feel?â€, the word â€œexhaustedâ€ acts as noise and should be excluded during inference. However, determining relevance necessitates considering â€œBobâ€ in the query alongside â€œAliceâ€, the subject of â€œexhaustedâ€. Therefore, identifying the relevance of a token demands information from multiple tokens, yet self-attention computes relationships only between pairs, making it challenging to address this issue within a single transformer layer.

Consider a simple scenario in which three tokens are sufficient to determine the relevance of a given token. The task is to ascertain whether there exists information indicating that token ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is noise relative to the query. Let gâ¢(ğ’™i,ğ’™a,ğ’™b)ğ‘”subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘subscriptğ’™ğ‘g({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{a},{\bm{x}}_{b})italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) be the function designed to identify whether tokens ğ’™asubscriptğ’™ğ‘{\bm{x}}_{a}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’™bsubscriptğ’™ğ‘{\bm{x}}_{b}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT suggest that token ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a relevant token, if gâ¢(ğ’™i,ğ’™a,ğ’™b)=0ğ‘”subscriptğ’™ğ‘–subscriptğ’™ğ‘subscriptğ’™ğ‘0g({\bm{x}}_{i},{\bm{x}}_{a},{\bm{x}}_{b})=0italic_g ( bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0, then xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a noise token, otherwise it is relevant. Thus, the problem can be framed as follows:

ri={0Â ifÂ â¢âˆƒa,bâ¢s.t.gâ¢(xi,xa,xb)=0,1Â else.Â subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–cases0formulae-sequenceÂ ifÂ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘01Â else.Â r_{i}=\begin{cases}0&\text{ if }\ \exists\ a,b\ s.t.\ g(x_{i},x_{a},x_{b})=0,% \\ 1&\text{ else. }\end{cases}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if âˆƒ italic_a , italic_b italic_s . italic_t . italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL else. end_CELL end_ROW

And we need a transformer based model â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}caligraphic_M to calculate ğ’“=â„³â¢(ğ‘¿)ğ’“â„³ğ‘¿{\bm{r}}={\mathcal{M}}({\bm{X}})bold_italic_r = caligraphic_M ( bold_italic_X ), and we can show that one layer of transformer can hardly complete the task.

Theorem 4.1.

For input documents of length nğ‘›nitalic_n, and a constant cğ‘citalic_c if mâ¢pâ¢Hâ‰¤câ‹…nâ¢Hâ¢(ğ°)/logâ¡logâ¡nğ‘šğ‘ğ»â‹…ğ‘ğ‘›ğ»ğ°ğ‘›mpH\leq c\cdot nH({\bm{w}})/\log\log nitalic_m italic_p italic_H â‰¤ italic_c â‹… italic_n italic_H ( bold_italic_w ) / roman_log roman_log italic_n, then there is no one layer transformer â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}caligraphic_M with embedding size mğ‘šmitalic_m, precision pğ‘pitalic_p and Hğ»Hitalic_H heads to judge the relevance of tokens.

Consequently, a single layer of multi-head attention struggles to assess the relevance of a token. As noted in Conjecture 19 of Sanford etÂ al. (2024), even multiple layers of multi-head attention may not effectively resolve this issue. The challenge arises from the triple-wise nature of the problem contrasted with the pair-wise nature of attention; the model can only evaluate a tokenâ€™s relevance when its embedding contains substantial information. For example, to assess the token â€œfatigueâ€ in the sentence â€œAlice is exhausted, but Bob is still very excited, showing no signs of fatigue. How does Bob feel?â€, the embedding must encompass information about its subject, â€œBobâ€, as well as contextual details from phrases like â€œno signs ofâ€ and â€œshowingâ€. Therefore, a significant amount of information must be incorporated into the embedding before any judgement can be made. However, a single layer of self-attention can only consider the input âˆ‘jai,jâ¢ğ’™jsubscriptğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ’™ğ‘—\sum_{j}a_{i,j}{\bm{x}}_{j}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which contains information up to mâ¢pğ‘šğ‘mpitalic_m italic_p, where mğ‘šmitalic_m represents the embedding dimension and pğ‘pitalic_p indicates precision. The term mâ¢pğ‘šğ‘mpitalic_m italic_p signifies the maximal entropy of the embedding, which means the maximal information the embedding can carry. This suggests that multiple attention layers may be necessary to encompass all relevant information effectively.

Furthermore, this method renders Assumption 2.3 unrealistic, as assessing relevance requires a deep understanding of the document, thereby increasing the number of layers necessary for effective information extraction. If we assume that tğ‘¡titalic_t layers are needed to evaluate relevance, then extracting information about node ul,jsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘—u_{l,j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would require Î»â‹…l+tâ‹…ğœ†ğ‘™ğ‘¡\lambda\cdot l+titalic_Î» â‹… italic_l + italic_t layers. This could potentially exceed lğ‘™litalic_l, and extracting information from documents may necessitate a greater reasoning depth than standard reasoning. Consequently, nodes located below layer t1âˆ’Î»ğ‘¡1ğœ†\frac{t}{1-\lambda}divide start_ARG italic_t end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Î» end_ARG cannot access document information because their reasoning would be finished faster than information extraction of documents. Then the reasoning depth cannot be easily reduced, as it primarily occurs in the lower layers. Therefore, leveraging document information may not enhance reasoning ability; in fact, it could potentially degrade performance if the model becomes overly reliant on document information rather than employing vanilla reasoning.

4.2 Simplicify the Problem

Therefore, reducing the number of layers required for filtering is essential to enhancing the reasoning ability of retrieval-augmented language models (RALMs). In the retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) setting, we can simplify the triple-wise problem. By precalculating information from the document and representing this summarized information as one or a few additional tokens (virtual prompt tokens), we can evaluate the relevance of a token using only the information from the token itself, the query, and the summarized document.

This approach simplifies the problem to:

ri={0Â ifÂ â¢âˆƒa,bâ¢s.t.gâ¢(xi,xv,xb)=0,1Â else.Â subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–cases0formulae-sequenceÂ ifÂ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘01Â else.Â r_{i}=\begin{cases}0&\text{ if }\ \exists\ a,b\ s.t.\ g(x_{i},x_{v},x_{b})=0,% \\ 1&\text{ else. }\end{cases}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if âˆƒ italic_a , italic_b italic_s . italic_t . italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL else. end_CELL end_ROW

where xvsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£x_{v}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the virtual prompt token. By fixing the position of one token, we can utilize the first transformer layer to aggregate information of xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and xvsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£x_{v}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In the second layer, the problem is actually a pair-wise one because xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT already hold enough information about xvsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘£x_{v}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and xbsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘x_{b}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are enough to judge the relevance. This approach effectively reformulates the triple-wise problem into pair-wise one, which the transformer can more readily address within a single layer. This could be done because we fix the position of one information, then the triple-wise problem becomes two pair-wise problem. Otherwise, we need to incorporate plenty of information before final judgement, because we do not know which one could be useful when judging the relevance. With the virtual document token, we summarize those information about judging the relevance in a fixed position, and we can easily gather those information for final judgement

However, most large language models (LLMs) are trained in an autoregressive manner, meaning that a token cannot aggregate information from any tokens that appear later in the sequence; thus, ai,j=0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—0a_{i,j}=0italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 if j>iğ‘—ğ‘–j>iitalic_j > italic_i. Typically, the query is positioned after the document tokens, preventing these document tokens from assessing their relevance effectively. Consequently, the relevance judgement must occur during the calculation of the query embedding, complicating the assessment process and limiting the modelâ€™s ability to utilize document information to judge the relevance.

Instead, if we position the query ahead of documents, then the relevance can be effectively calculated for document tokens. This arrangement enables the information of query to be effectively transferred to the document tokens for relevance judgement. Therefore, we can hypothesize that when there is noise in the document, placing the query at the beginning would help the judgement.

Considering the scenario where we aim to judge the relevance of the first token of the documents, with the relevance being determined by the first token of the query (a pair-wise situation), we can demonstrate that placing the query ahead is beneficial.

Proposition 4.2.

Using auto-regressive transformer to solve the pair-wise problem requires mâ¢pâ‰¥(ndâ¢oâ¢câ¢uâ¢mâ¢eâ¢nâ¢t+1)â¢Hâ¢(ğ°)ğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡1ğ»ğ°mp\geq(n_{document}+1)H({\bm{w}})italic_m italic_p â‰¥ ( italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_c italic_u italic_m italic_e italic_n italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 ) italic_H ( bold_italic_w ). Putting the query ahead only requires mâ¢pâ‰¥2â¢Hâ¢(ğ°)ğ‘šğ‘2ğ»ğ°mp\geq 2H({\bm{w}})italic_m italic_p â‰¥ 2 italic_H ( bold_italic_w ), where ndâ¢oâ¢câ¢uâ¢mâ¢eâ¢nâ¢tsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘¢ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘¡n_{document}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_o italic_c italic_u italic_m italic_e italic_n italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the number of documents.

This is primarily because documents cannot assess their relevance when the query is placed after them. In this scenario, the query must evaluate the relevance of all documents. However, if the query is positioned first, the documents can independently assess their own relevance.

We conduct experiments on three models with a subset of NQ (Kwiatkowski etÂ al., 2019), more details about the experiment is shown in Appendix D. As shown in Table 1, positioning the query ahead significantly enhances performance. The term â€goldâ€ refers to the configuration â€query, gold-documentâ€ indicating that the query is placed before the documents, with only the gold document (which contains the answer) included. In contrast, â€disâ€ represents the configuration â€query, gold-document, distraction-documentâ€ where one distracting document is incorporated. The notation â€gold-r dis-râ€ signifies that the query has been placed both ahead and after of the documents. It is clear that this arrangement improves performance across all three models except for vicuna when faced with distraction, we assume that this is mainly because vicuna is finetuned on a conversation dataset, which makes the model already capable of handling distracting documents, and the reversed query document order have negative impact on the filtering process.

5 DPrompt tuning

As stated in the previous section, effectively addressing this problem requires the use of virtual tokens at the beginning of the prompt to represent the documentâ€™s information. To accomplish this, we propose training an additional model to extract information from the document and utilize the embeddings to encapsulate this information. We then append these virtual tokens to the front of the prompt before conducting inference.

It is important to note that the model used for information extraction does not impose any additional inference costs on the LLM, because the calculations are solely based on the document, This allows us to precalculate the embeddings and directly retrieve the information while retrieving documents, ensuring that there is no extra cost during inference.

Specifically, we fine-tune a BERT-base-uncased model with an additional multi-layer perceptron (MLP) to project the embeddings to the appropriate dimensions. Given an input prompt, we identify the relevant documents, encode them as virtual tokens, and then inject these tokens at the front of the prompt.

Additionally, we perform inference with the query both before and after the documents to optimize performance. And we put the virtual tokens represents the documents before the query for all tokens to effectively take advantage of the virtual token. We also employ LoRA fine-tuning methods to enhance the modelâ€™s ability to leverage the information in the virtual document tokens.

We conduct experiments using a subset of Natural Questions (NQ) dataset (Kwiatkowski etÂ al., 2019), we utilize Contriever to extract documents, treating those that do not contain the answer as distracting documents (Cuconasu etÂ al., 2024). Itâ€™s important to note that while the gold documents contain relevant information, they also include significant amounts of noise. More experimental details are shown in Appendix D.

In the â€goldâ€ configuration, the prompt contains only the query and one gold document, which is the most relevant to the query. The â€gold disâ€ configuration includes one gold document along with two distracting documents in the input prompt.

From Table 2, we can see that DPrompt tuning achieves significant performance improvements across all three models. This indicates that adding virtual tokens at the beginning enhances the LLMâ€™s ability to distinguish irrelevant information. However, there are instances where the LoRA-fine-tuned model performs worse than the vanilla reasoning with RAG, aligning with previous findings that fine-tuned RALM may performs worse (Lakatos etÂ al., 2024). We also conduct experiments with regular order (query ahead of documents) and we put the result in Appendix D.2

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we highlight that while RAG can enhance the reasoning capabilities of LLMs, it often only expands a limited number of reasoning depth unless we directly obtain information leading to the answer. However, noise within the documents can negatively affect performance, and processing these documents demands a certain depth of reasoning, we further demonstrate that filtering irrelevant information cannot be achieved within a few transformer layers due to its intrinsic triple-wise nature. To address this, we propose a method called DPrompt tuning which allows for effective resolution within few layers of the transformer.

Appendix A Expressive Power of RAG

A.1 Proof of Theorem 2.4

Assume there is a tree of Lğ¿Litalic_L layers and each layer has nlsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘™n_{l}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT nodes, the top of the tree got only one node. There are connections between the layer and its upper layer, the probability of connection is 1âˆ’ql1subscriptğ‘ğ‘™1-q_{l}1 - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if node ul,isubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘–u_{l,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not connected to any node, than we randomly sample a node and set the connection, the probability of no connection is obviously qlnl+1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘›ğ‘™1q_{l}^{n_{l+1}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

The connection can be regarded as reasoning paths, and RAG can ignore the reasoning path, directly give the answer corresponding to node ul,isubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘–u_{l,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ul,isubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘–u_{l,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stands for the itâ¢hsuperscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡â„i^{th}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT node of the ltâ¢hsuperscriptğ‘™ğ‘¡â„l^{th}italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT layer. Assume that node ul,isubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘–u_{l,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is retrived by RAG, then all the downstream nodes connect to and only to node ul,isubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘–u_{l,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can also be erased.

Assume in layer l+1ğ‘™1l+1italic_l + 1, rl+1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1r_{l+1}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT nodes are erased, then for layer lğ‘™litalic_l, let n=nl+1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘™1n=n_{l+1}italic_n = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the probability of nodes being erased is,

pe=(1âˆ’qlrl+1)â¢qlnâˆ’rl+1+qlnâ¢rl+1nsubscriptğ‘ğ‘’1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1ğ‘›p_{e}=(1-q_{l}^{r_{l+1}})q_{l}^{n-r_{l+1}}+q_{l}^{n}\frac{r_{l+1}}{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG (4)

1âˆ’qlrl+11superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™11-q_{l}^{r_{l+1}}1 - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT means it connects to at least one of the rl+1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1r_{l+1}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT nodes, and qlnâˆ’rl+1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1q_{l}^{n-r_{l+1}}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT means that it is not connected to other nodes. So the first item (1âˆ’qlrl+1)â¢qlnâˆ’rl+11superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1(1-q_{l}^{r_{l+1}})q_{l}^{n-r_{l+1}}( 1 - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT means that when the node is connected to at least one of the rl+1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘™1r_{l+1}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT nodes, and not connected to other nodes. Also, RAG can retrieve some information about layer lğ‘™litalic_l, Assume that with probability plsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™p_{l}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, RAG retrieves information about node ul,isubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘–u_{l,i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then, the percentage of node erased by converge and RAG are tlsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™t_{l}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, nğ‘›nitalic_n stands for the number of nodes in layer l+1ğ‘™1l+1italic_l + 1

italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = ( ( 1 - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‹… italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - ( ( 1 - italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‹… italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL = italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 + divide start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG ) + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ğ”¼â¢(tl)=p=(qlnâˆ’plâ¢qln)â¢(qlâˆ’kâ¢tl+1âˆ’1+tl+1)+plğ”¼subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™11subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘ğ‘™\mathbb{E}(t_{l})=p=\left(q_{l}^{n}-p_{l}q_{l}^{n}\right)\left(q_{l}^{-kt_{l+1% }}-1+t_{l+1}\right)+p_{l}blackboard_E ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_p = ( italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

tlsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™t_{l}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT stands for the percentage of nodes could be erased, consider a function fâ¢(t)ğ‘“ğ‘¡f(t)italic_f ( italic_t ) where
