For simplicity, we use n=ndğ‘›subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘n=n_{d}italic_n = italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Now consider a more complex situation where Alice and Bob each hold a matrix ğ‘¨âˆˆâ„nÃ—dğ‘¨superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘{\bm{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}bold_italic_A âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ‘©âˆˆâ„nÃ—dğ‘©superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘{\bm{B}}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}bold_italic_B âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. each row of the matrix contains ğ’˜ğ’˜{\bm{w}}bold_italic_w, so d=Hâ¢(ğ’˜)ğ‘‘ğ»ğ’˜d=H({\bm{w}})italic_d = italic_H ( bold_italic_w ). and we assume that ğ’™=[ğ’”,ğ’˜]ğ’™ğ’”ğ’˜{\bm{x}}=[{\bm{s}},{\bm{w}}]bold_italic_x = [ bold_italic_s , bold_italic_w ].

Then

ğ’™i={ğ’™iifâ¢i=0,[ğ’”,ğ’‚i]ifâ¢iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,ndâˆ’1},[ğ’”,ğ’ƒi]ifâ¢iâˆˆ{nd,â€¦,2â‹…ndâˆ’1}.subscriptğ’™ğ‘–casessubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ifğ‘–0ğ’”subscriptğ’‚ğ‘–ifğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘1ğ’”subscriptğ’ƒğ‘–ifğ‘–subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘â€¦â‹…2subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘1{\bm{x}}_{i}=\begin{cases}{\bm{x}}_{i}&\text{if}\ i=0,\\ [{\bm{s}},{\bm{a}}_{i}]&\text{if}\ i\in\{1,\dots,n_{d}-1\},\\ [{\bm{s}},{\bm{b}}_{i}]&\text{if}\ i\in\{n_{d},\dots,2\cdot n_{d}-1\}.\end{cases}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i = 0 , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL [ bold_italic_s , bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i âˆˆ { 1 , â€¦ , italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 } , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL [ bold_italic_s , bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_CELL start_CELL if italic_i âˆˆ { italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , 2 â‹… italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 } . end_CELL end_ROW (18)

Let DISJ1â¢(ğ‘¨,ğ‘©)=maxiâ¡(gâ€²â¢(ğ’™,ğ’‚i,ğ’ƒi))DISJ1ğ‘¨ğ‘©subscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘”â€²ğ’™subscriptğ’‚ğ‘–subscriptğ’ƒğ‘–\mathrm{DISJ1}({\bm{A}},{\bm{B}})=\max_{i}(g^{\prime}({\bm{x}},{\bm{a}}_{i},{% \bm{b}}_{i}))DISJ1 ( bold_italic_A , bold_italic_B ) = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_x , bold_italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), where the function gâ€²superscriptğ‘”â€²g^{\prime}italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT acts similar with gğ‘”gitalic_g, but it takes ğ’‚,ğ’ƒğ’‚ğ’ƒ{\bm{a}},{\bm{b}}bold_italic_a , bold_italic_b as input, and ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}bold_italic_x is a fixed constant as ğ’™isubscriptğ’™ğ‘–{\bm{x}}_{i}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. So the calculation of Dâ¢Iâ¢Sâ¢Jâ¢1ğ·ğ¼ğ‘†ğ½1DISJ1italic_D italic_I italic_S italic_J 1 requires nÃ—Hâ¢(ğ’˜)ğ‘›ğ»ğ’˜n\times H({\bm{w}})italic_n Ã— italic_H ( bold_italic_w ) bits of communication.

Also similar to the setting of xğ‘¥xitalic_x, ri=1subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–1r_{i}=1italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 if and only if DISJ1â¢(ğ‘¨,ğ‘©)=1DISJ1ğ‘¨ğ‘©1\mathrm{DISJ1}({\bm{A}},{\bm{B}})=1DISJ1 ( bold_italic_A , bold_italic_B ) = 1.

Then, this is the same with the 3Match problem, following the proof of Theorem 7 in Sanford etÂ al. (2024), and with the following form of transformer fâ¢(ğ‘¿)ğ‘“ğ‘¿f({\bm{X}})italic_f ( bold_italic_X ), 2â¢pâ¢Hâ¢logâ¡logâ¡n+mâ¢pâ¢Hâ¢logâ¡logâ¡nâ‰ˆmâ¢pâ¢Hâ¢logâ¡logâ¡n2ğ‘ğ»ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ»ğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘ğ»ğ‘›2pH\log\log n+mpH\log\log n\approx mpH\log\log n2 italic_p italic_H roman_log roman_log italic_n + italic_m italic_p italic_H roman_log roman_log italic_n â‰ˆ italic_m italic_p italic_H roman_log roman_log italic_n bits are communicated.

fâ¢(ğ‘¿)=Ï•â¢(fhâ¢(ğ‘¿)),ğ‘“ğ‘¿italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘“â„ğ‘¿f({\bm{X}})=\phi(f_{h}({\bm{X}})),italic_f ( bold_italic_X ) = italic_Ï• ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_X ) ) ,

where Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• stands for the feed forward layers.

fhâ¢(ğ‘¿)=âˆ‘i=1Nexpâ¡((ğ‘¾qâ¢x1)Tâ¢ğ‘¾kâ¢xi)â¢ğ‘¾vâ¢xiâˆ‘i=1Nexpâ¡((ğ‘¾qâ¢x1)Tâ¢ğ‘¾kâ¢xi)subscriptğ‘“â„ğ‘¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–f_{h}({\bm{X}})=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\exp\left(({\bm{W}}_{q}x_{1})^{T}{\bm{W}}_% {k}x_{i}\right){\bm{W}}_{v}x_{i}}{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\exp\left(({\bm{W}}_{q}x_{1})^% {T}{\bm{W}}_{k}x_{i}\right)}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_X ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( ( bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( ( bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG

Therefore, only we require mâ¢pâ¢Hâ¢logâ¡logâ¡nâ‰¥nâ¢Hâ¢(ğ’˜)â†’mâ¢pâ¢hâ‰¥nâ¢Hâ¢(ğ’˜)/logâ¡logâ¡nğ‘šğ‘ğ»ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ»ğ’˜â†’ğ‘šğ‘â„ğ‘›ğ»ğ’˜ğ‘›mpH\log\log n\geq nH({\bm{w}})\rightarrow mph\geq nH({\bm{w}})/\log\log nitalic_m italic_p italic_H roman_log roman_log italic_n â‰¥ italic_n italic_H ( bold_italic_w ) â†’ italic_m italic_p italic_h â‰¥ italic_n italic_H ( bold_italic_w ) / roman_log roman_log italic_n.

Theorem C.2.

For input documents of length nğ‘›nitalic_n, if mâ¢pâ¢Hâ‰¤Î©â¢(nâ¢Hâ¢(ğ°)/logâ¡logâ¡n)ğ‘šğ‘ğ»Î©ğ‘›ğ»ğ°ğ‘›mpH\leq\Omega(nH({\bm{w}})/\log\log n)italic_m italic_p italic_H â‰¤ roman_Î© ( italic_n italic_H ( bold_italic_w ) / roman_log roman_log italic_n ), then there is no one layer transformer â„³â„³{\mathcal{M}}caligraphic_M with embedding size mğ‘šmitalic_m, precision pğ‘pitalic_p and Hğ»Hitalic_H heads satisfying â„³â¢(X)=râ„³ğ‘‹ğ‘Ÿ{\mathcal{M}}(X)=rcaligraphic_M ( italic_X ) = italic_r.

Also, as shown in Sanford etÂ al. (2024), multiple layers of multi-headed attention are subject to the same impossibility

Conjecture C.3.

Every multi-layer transformer that computes Match3 must have width, depth, embedding dimension, or bit complexity at least NÎ©â¢(1)superscriptğ‘Î©1N^{\Omega(1)}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î© ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

However, one layer of transformer can effectively solve Match2 problem, for RAG, we can simply fix one or some token to represent the information of a document, in this way gâ¢(xi,xa,xb)ğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘g(x_{i},x_{a},x_{b})italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) becomes gâ¢(xi,x0,xb)ğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘g(x_{i},x_{0},x_{b})italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), if we use the first transformer layer to aggregrate information of xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then use the second layer to gather xbsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘x_{b}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and judging the relevance by MLP layers, then the problem can be solved.

therefore, gâ¢(xi,xa,xb)=gâ¢(xi,xa,xb)=gâ€²â¢(xiâ€²,xbâ€²)ğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptğ‘”â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘â€²g(x_{i},x_{a},x_{b})=g(x_{i},x_{a},x_{b})=g^{\prime}(x_{i}^{\prime},x_{b}^{% \prime})italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then the problem becomes a pair-wise problem, and transformer can easily solve it.

Proposition C.4.

Using transformer to solve ri={0Â ifÂ â¢âˆƒa,bâ¢s.t.gâ€²â¢(xiâ€²,xbâ€²)=01Â elseÂ subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–cases0formulae-sequenceÂ ifÂ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘”â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘â€²01Â elseÂ r_{i}=\begin{cases}0&\text{ if }\ \exists\ a,b\ s.t.\ g^{\prime}(x_{i}^{\prime% },x_{b}^{\prime})=0\\ 1&\text{ else }\end{cases}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if âˆƒ italic_a , italic_b italic_s . italic_t . italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL else end_CELL end_ROW requires mâ¢pâ¢Hâ¢Dâ‰¥ndâ¢Hâ¢(ğ°)ğ‘šğ‘ğ»ğ·subscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ»ğ°mpHD\geq n_{d}H({\bm{w}})italic_m italic_p italic_H italic_D â‰¥ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H ( bold_italic_w ).

This mainly dues to the self regression of LLM, token xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can not gather information of token xjsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—x_{j}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if j>iğ‘—ğ‘–j>iitalic_j > italic_i, which means that all the judgement of is done during the calculation of query rather than the document tokens because we put the documents ahead of the query. However, if we put the query first, then gâ€²â¢(xi,xb)superscriptğ‘”â€²subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘g^{\prime}(x_{i},x_{b})italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) can be effectively calculated in the document token.

Appendix D Experiments

We conduct experiments using the Natural Questions (NQ) dataset (Kwiatkowski etÂ al., 2019), which is a large-scale collection of real-world queries derived from Google search data. Each entry consists of a user query and the corresponding Wikipedia page that contains the answer. We utilize Contriever to extract documents, treating those that do not contain the answer as distracting documents (Cuconasu etÂ al., 2024). Due to the limited computational resource, we only sample 1000 queries to test the performance.

we use different task instruction when query is ahead or after the documents.

  • â€¢

    query ahead document: â€You are given a question and you MUST respond with a short answer (max 5 tokens) based on the provided documents. If none of the documents contain the answer and you do not know the answer, please respond with NO-RES.â€

  • â€¢

    query after document: You are given a question and you MUST respond with a short answer (max 5 tokens) based on the provided documents. If none of the documents contain the answer and you do not know the answer, please respond with NO-RES. The question will be presented both before and after the documents.

Also, in the query after document situation, we actually also put the query after the documents to make LLM remember what the question is.

We conduct experiments on a single Nvidia RTX 3090 24G, the rank for LoRA finetuning is 64646464, and we use 1,8,15 virtual tokens for prompt tuning and find the best performing one. We finetuning the learning rate with in {5â¢eâˆ’7,1â¢eâˆ’6,3â¢eâˆ’6,5â¢eâˆ’6,1â¢eâˆ’5}5ğ‘’71ğ‘’63ğ‘’65ğ‘’61ğ‘’5\{5e-7,1e-6,3e-6,5e-6,1e-5\}{ 5 italic_e - 7 , 1 italic_e - 6 , 3 italic_e - 6 , 5 italic_e - 6 , 1 italic_e - 5 }.

We use three models to show the performance.

  • â€¢

    meta-llama/Meta-Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct

  • â€¢

    lmsys/vicuna-7b-v1.5

  • â€¢

    mistralai/Mistral-7B-Instruct-v0.3

Due to limited computational resources, we sample 1,000 queries for training, and we use the code of Cuconasu etÂ al. (2024) to extract those gold and distracting documents.

D.1 RAG brings more sparsity

When we implement RAG, it may struggle to reduce many layers, but it effectively helps to decrease numerous nodes, introducing some sparsity to LLMs. In Figure 1, Document 1 contains information about u2,2subscriptğ‘¢22u_{2,2}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which can aid in reducing the calculations for nodes u1,2,u1,3subscriptğ‘¢12subscriptğ‘¢13u_{1,2},u_{1,3}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and so on. This allows for the pruning of certain parameters used to compute these nodes, resulting in a sparser LLM when utilizing RAG.

To verify this, we conduct experiments on the NQ dataset, employing the Wanda pruning method (Sun etÂ al., 2023). Specifically, the pruning parameters are assessed based on their score, which is defined as

Si,j=|Wi,j|â‹…â€–Xjâ€–2,subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—â‹…subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—2S_{i,j}=|W_{i,j}|\cdot||X_{j}||_{2},italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‹… | | italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where |Wi,j|subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘—|W_{i,j}|| italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | represents the absolute value of the parameter, while Xjsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—X_{j}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the input. The score is evaluated as the product of its magnitude and the norm of the corresponding input activations, which directly indicates the importance of each parameter for the inference.

We utilize the query along with one relevant document that directly contains information related to the query as input. As expected, with increasing sparsity, conducting inference using only the query leads to worse performance. However, inference with RAG maintains similar performance until the model becomes too sparse to retrieve information from the documents. Also as sparsity increases, the fine-tuned model gradually outperforms the vanilla model with RAG because the fine-tuned version can stop calculating certain nodes and focus on other computations with limited parameters. While using RAG in LLMs can enhance performance, it does not fully leverage the sparse nature of RALM. Consequently, as sparsity increases, the fine-tuned RAG surpasses the regular RAG.

D.2 Experiments on query document order

In Table 3, we show the performance when the prompt is in regular order, which means that we put the documents ahead of the query. We can observe that although DPrompt tuning performs best, the improvement is not as significant as the reversed order, which shows that the reversed order can actually help when faced with irrelevant information

Appendix E Related Work

Many recent works have explored better RAG strategies. Shi etÂ al. (2023b) treat the model as a black box and design a retriever to enhance performance. However, Shi etÂ al. (2023a) found that distracting documents in the retrieved set significantly weaken performance, leading some to address this by fine-tuning the LLM (Yoran etÂ al., 2023; Zhang etÂ al., 2024). Additionally, researchers have identified that noise in the prompt can negatively impact performance, prompting efforts to eliminate this noise and compress prompts (Jiang etÂ al., 2023b; a; Pan etÂ al., 2024). Xu etÂ al. (2024) first highlighted the duality of RAG, encompassing both benefits and detriments. Understanding how these factors influence the reasoning capabilities of LLMs remains an open question.

Merrill & Sabharwal (2023) proves that the expressive power of LLM is constrained to Tâ¢C0ğ‘‡superscriptğ¶0TC^{0}italic_T italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, but Feng etÂ al. (2024); Li etÂ al. (2024) shows that by Chain of Thought prompting, we can infinitely stack transformer layers to solve any DP problems, Zeng & Lee (2023) further prove the rank needed to adapt the model for other takss by LoRA, and Petrov etÂ al. (2024) shows that prompt tuning can be a universal approximator with enough prompt length, while prompt tuning fail to change the attention pattern and can only bias the output (Petrov etÂ al., 2023). RAG is also one kind of prompting technique, and it also try to involve more information when conducting inference like CoT. But how does RAG helps to improve the expressive power of LLM has not been studied before.
